- AWS is building a more
sustainable business
because that is what our customers want.

And one of the ways we are
driving sustainability at our

data centers is by expanding
our circular economy efforts.
I'm Manju Murugesan,

and I work on the
sustainability team here at AWS.

Our strategy for accelerating
our transition towards
circularity is based on three pillars.

Design better, operate
longer, and recover more.
By designing better,
we unlock more potential than at any other
stage of circularity.

We design to avoid waste by
eliminating excess materials,
enabling more reuse and recycling,
and using materials that are safer
for people and the environment.

Next, we plan to operate longer
through robust maintenance

of data center hardware
to avoid early retirement.

At AWS, we consolidate individual
functional hard drives from

multiple aging racks into
fewer fully functional racks.

Extending the lifespan of S3
hard drives by up to two years

by sending only broken
drives for recycling

and avoiding the early retirement
of healthy working drives

on the same rack, we increase
water and energy efficiency.

Finally, we aim to recover
more through repair
and reuse of used equipment,

we avoid the carbon and costs
associated with the purchase

and manufacture of new
components and materials.

AWS sends securely
decommissioned equipment

to our regional reverse logistics
hubs to assess, repair,

and recirculate functional
equipment back into inventory,
or to be sold for reuse by third parties.
By designing better, operating longer
and recovering more, we will continue
to expand on our circular economy efforts.

Our acceleration towards
circularity means we use today's

equipment to build tomorrows
charting, a path for AWS,
our customers and the global supply chain
to reach new levels of resource efficiency

and to build a more resilient
future for the planet.
